questions.text: Neena, a 50 year old woman was experiencing early morning stiffness and arthritis, which was relieved with exercising. She has previously tested positive for anti CCP antibodies and was accordingly started on DMARD's to which she had recently stopped responding. Her personal history is significant for hypertension. She is currently taking prednisolone, indomethacin, infliximab and telmisartan. Recently, she has been experiencing fever, night sweats and weight loss of >10% in 6 months. Her sputum tests positive for mycobacterial infection. Her physician informs her that she has developed reactivation of latent Tuberculosis due to one of the drugs she has been prescribed. Which of the above drugs is implicated in the same?
questions.solution:
• Infliximab is a biologic agent, which is a TNF-α TNFα amplifies immune inflammation by releasing other cytokines and enzymes like collagenases and metalloproteinases. The TNFα inhibitors are mainly used in autoimmune diseases such as RA.
  • TNF-α inhibitors are known to worsen latent TB, HIV, Hep-B, C. They may also worsen CHF.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 943

questions.text:
Mrs. Ramila is a known case of bipolar disorder, for which she has been on lithium therapy for the past 5 years. Her family and past history is insignificant. Recently, she has been experiencing excessive thirst and 'very pale urine'. She also experiences frequent myalgia and agitation since the onset of her urinary problems. On examination, her blood pressure was 156/76 mmHg, respiratory rate of 23/min, saturation 91% on room air, and a pulse rate of 101/min.
She was suspected to be experiencing a side effect from lithium therapy.
Her 24-urine output was 7L
urine osmolality of 316 mOsm/kg
serum sodium of 151 mEq/L
serum osmolality of 327 mOsm/kg
After desmopressin challenge, urine osmolality increased to 485 mOsm/Kg.
CT head was normal.
What is the first line therapy for this patient, considering that lithium cannot be stopped in her case?
questions.solution:
• The patient here is experiencing Lithium induced Diabetes Insipidus.
  • In this patient, her urine osmolality was 316 mOsm/Kg before the administration of desmopressin and the increase in osmolality was <50% afterward.
  • A diagnosis of lithium-induced partial nephrogenic diabetes insipidus was made based on the results of baseline osmolality and electrolytes, poor response to desmopressin, and no identifiable etiology of central causes of diabetes insipidus, and in the context of the patient being on chronic lithium therapy for a duration of 5 years.
  • Patients who are on chronic lithium therapy can develop resistance to antidiuretic hormone (ADH) that results in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.
  • ADH acts on the principal cells in the collecting tubules regulating the water permeability.
  • It causes the fusion of aquaporin-2 (AQP2) water channels with the luminal membrane in principal cells, causing water absorption.
  • Lithium enters the principal cells through epithelial sodium channels in the luminal membrane and affects the ADH function on the cells. Several mechanisms have been suggested by which lithium interferes with ADH function. These include reducing AQP2 water channels by degradation and reducing AQP2 gene transcription decreasing the number of principal cells
  • Amiloride is considered one of the first-line medications to treat lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, particularly in those patients who need to be on lithium therapy despite the development of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Amiloride acts by blocking lithium entry into collecting tubules by closing sodium channels and so lithium cannot interfere in the function of ADH in these cells.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 637

questions.text: A 76-year-old female presented to the ER after having symptoms of shortness of breath and confusion. Her past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, coronary artery disease, and she was an everyday smoker for 30 years. She reports her daily medications are lisinopril and simvastatin. Her vitals are blood pressure of 138/70, heart rate of 108. respiratory rate of 26, temperature 98.9°F, and oxygen saturation of 84% on room air. Her initial assessment included alert and oriented to person and place, dyspnea, inspiratory crackles in bilateral lungs, and a cough with pink frothy sputum. Her labs and diagnostics resulted in a BNP of 740 pg/ml, an echocardiogram showing an ejection fraction of 35%. She was started on furosemide IV and digoxin. If this combination of medications is given together, what parameters should be monitored?
questions.solution:
• The clinical vignette describes a case of Left Ventricular failure, systolic in nature, causing pulmonary edema.
  • Furosemide is the first line drug to mobilize edema fluid in cases of CHF and has a rapid response.
  • Digoxin improves cardiac contractility by inhibiting Na-K ATPase pump.
  • However, loop diuretics and digoxin are avoided giving together because hypokalemia induced by Furosemide can worsen digoxin toxicity.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 632

questions.text:
The ECG of a patient presenting with chest pain and palpitations is given below.

The patient has a history of bronchial asthma since 12 years well controlled on albuterol. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
• The above ECG strip shows PSVT. the drug of choice for this condition is a rapid push of I.V adenosine. However, adenosine may produce bronchoconstriction.
  • Thus, it is contraindicated in Bronchial Asthma and COPD. The drug of choice in these cases is I.V Verapamil, which is a calcium channel blocker.
  • An attack of PSVT can be terminated by reflex vagal stimulation through Valsalva maneuver, splashing ice cold water on face, hyperflexion (head between knees), etc.
  • Alternatively, or if it does not work, the drug of choice is adenosine (i.v.).
  • Other alternatives are i.v. injection of verapamil/ diltiazem/esmolol. To prevent recurrences, oral therapy with verapamil, diltiazem or propranolol alone or combined with digoxin may be prescribed.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 581

questions.text: A patient of acute CHF was administered an inodilator, inamrinone. Which blood profile will you monitor when this drug is administered?
questions.solution:
• Inamrinone (amrinone) is a bipyridine derivative is a selective phosphodiesterase 3 (PDE3) inhibitor. The PDE3 isoenzyme is specific for intracellular degradation of cAMP in heart, blood vessels and bronchial smooth muscles. Amrinone increases myocardial cAMP and transmembrane influx of Ca2+. Both these actions may underlie its positive inotropic property.
  • The two most important actions of inamrinone are positive inotropy and direct vasodilatation. It has been called an 'inodilator'. Both preload and afterload on the heart is reduced. Compared to dobutamine, proportionately greater decrease in systemic vascular resistance is noted.
  • In CHF patients i.v. inamrinone acts rapidly and its action lasts for 2-3 hours; elimination t1⁄2 is 2-4 hours. It increases cardiac output and decreases peripheral vascular resistance, CVP and left ventricular end diastolic volume, accompanied by mild tachycardia and slight fall in BP.
  • Thrombocytopenia is the most prominent and dose related adverse effect.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 568

questions.text:
A 60-year old man with a previous history of type 2 DM for more than 25 years, treated with Metformin initially and insulin for the last 5 years, and with poor metabolic control presents with complaints of generalized oedema of one month duration, dyspnea, nocturia. On physical examination, the patient was in good general condition, was conscious and oriented. Blood pressure was 160/110 mm Hg, heart rate 80 beats/min. His current HbA1c is 9.9%.
Blood analysis revealed-
Glucose 200mg/dl
Urea 52mg/dl
Creatinine 1.2mg/dl
Uric acid 5.3mg/dl
Cholesterol 313mg/dl
Triglycerides 144mg/dl,
Albumin 1.9g/dl
Total protein 4.4g/dl
The urinalysis revealed protein +++, blood + glucose ++ and negative nitrite. Proteinuria in 24-hour urine collection was 10g. In urine electrophoresis, proteinuria was non-selective, with the Bence-Jones proteinuria negative. The doctor makes a diagnosis of diabetic nephropathy. Which of the following drugs prevents progression to end stage renal disease in such patients?
questions.solution:
• ACEI and ARB's(Telmisartan in this case) have been found to prevent or delay endstage renal disease in type I as well as type II diabetics. Albuminuria (an index of glomerulopathy) remains stable in those treated with ACE inhibitors, but aggravates in untreated diabetics.
  • Treated patients have higher creatinine clearance, require less dialysis and have longer life expectancy.
  • Benefits appear to be due to hemodynamic (systemic and intrarenal) as well as abnormal mesangial cell growth attenuating effects of these drugs. They reduce intraglomerular pressure and hyperfiltration.
  • ACE inhibitors arrest/partly reverse any degree of albuminuria, but benefits in type 2 diabetics are rather limited once macroalbuminuria has set in.
  • The RAS seems to accentuate micro and macrovascular complications in diabetics, and ACE inhibitors have specific organ protective effects by attenuating the same. ARB's are also reno-protective and are now preferred due to better tolerability.
    • /ul>

    Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 535

questions.text:
Mrs. Malti was prescribed a certain second line antihypertensive. However, one month later, she developed the following side effect.

What is the mechanism of action of the drug which she was prescribed?
questions.solution:
• The side effect shown is hirsutism in females, typically caused by minoxidil. Its active metabolite opens ATP sensitive K+ channels and causes vasodilation by hyperpolarization.
  • Since it causes hirsutism, it is now used to promote hair growth in Male pattern baldness and Alopecia Areata. Baldness however recurs when therapy is discontinued.
  • Phenoxybenzamine is a non-selective alpha blocker and it does not cause hirsutism.
  • Beta blockers cause dysglycemia, bronchoconstriction etc.
  • ARB's are known to cause hyperkalemia and renal artery stenosis

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 613

questions.text: Rohit is a 54-year-old male on treatment for ischemic heart disease. He has a history of hypertension, hypertriglyceridemia and diabetes mellitus. Thus, he has been prescribed valsartan, simvastatin and sitagliptin + Metformin for the same. He also takes tablet metoprolol for IHD. recently, he had an episode of angina, for which he was prescribed another second line anti anginal. Following this, he developed painful lesions in his mouth as shown below. Which of the following drugs may have been prescribed to her?
questions.solution:
• The image shows painful aphthous ulcers, which are a side effect of nicorandil. These are known to be healed by stopping the drug.
  • Trimetazidine has an increased risk of movement disorders
  • Ivabradine causes luminous phenomena, wherein bright spots are seen on the visual field

Side effects of nicorandil

Flushing, palpitation, weakness, headache, dizziness, nausea and vomiting.

Large painful aphthous ulcers in the mouth, which heal on stopping nicorandil have been reported.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 599

questions.text: A man on metoprolol therapy for IHD presents with a new onset attack of angina. A new antianginal is to be added in him. The resident doctor on duty accidentally prescribes verapamil to this patient without seeing his existing prescription. Which of the following may be seen on ECG in this patient when this combination of drugs is given?
questions.solution:
• Both beta blockers and non DHP calcium channel blockers have cardio-depressant properties.
  • Thus, they must not be prescribed together, since they may add to each other's effects and cause complete AV block, sinus depression and asystole

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 594

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman, Cherry, with a history of hypertension without any treatment for 5 years presented with chest tightness, palpitations and sweating. Vital signs on arrival indicated blood pressure of 178/120 mmHg. Twelve-lead electrocardiogram indicated ST-segment depression in leads II, III, aVF, and V3-V6 and QT prolongation. Coronary angiogram revealed no evidence of coronary artery disease. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography demonstrated an inhomogeneous right adrenal mass (2.5 × 3.0 cm). Her 24-h urinary norepinephrine and catecholamine levels were elevated. The patient underwent laparoscopic right adrenalectomy. Histopathology confirmed adrenal pheochromocytoma with residual necrosis. The patient was diagnosed with pheochromocytoma. For controlling hypertension intra-op, the patient was administered an alpha blocker followed by a beta blocker. What is the mechanism of action of the alpha blocker being administered?
questions.solution:
• Phenoxybenzamine is the drug of choice for controlling Hypertensive episodes in Pheochromocytoma.
  • It is a halogenated alkylamine that cyclizes spontaneously in the body giving rise to a highly reactive ethylene minimum intermediate which reacts with α adrenoceptors and other biomolecules by forming strong covalent bonds.
  • The α blockade is of nonequilibrium (irreversible) type and develops gradually (even after i.v. injection) and lasts for 3-4 days till fresh receptors are synthesized. Thus, it is a hit and run drug.
  • The fall in BP caused by phenoxybenzamine is mainly postural because veno-dilatation is more prominent than arteriolar dilatation.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 154

questions.text: Given below is a graph of the effect of 3 sympathomimetics on blood pressure and heart rate. Of these, what is the first drug likely to be?
questions.solution:
• The above graph shows a rise in BP and a decrease in heart rate due to reflex tachycardia.
  • This is seen with drugs such as noradrenaline, which have alpha1 and beta-1 action. It causes rise in bp due to its alpha-1 action, but no Vaso-dilation (no alpha-2 action)

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 143

questions.text: Mr. Ibrahim is a 48-year-old shop attendant who presented at the eye unit of a teaching hospital with a history of gradual, painless vision loss. His presenting (unaided) visual acuity was counting fingers at 1 meter in the right eye and 6/60 in the left eye. Both corneas were clear, and the pupils had a slow reaction to light. There was a right relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD). The right eye had a nuclear sclerotic cataract which precluded a good view of the optic nerve head, and a vertical cup: disc ratio (VCDR) of about 0.9, barely visible through the dilated pupil with the binocular indirect ophthalmoscope. The left eye VCDR was 0.8. Intraocular pressure (IOP) was 32 mmHg (right eye) and 30 mmHg (left eye) by applanation tonometry. Gonioscopy showed open angles in both eyes. The ophthalmologist decides to prescribe a drug that increases uveoscleral outflow. Which of the following may not have been prescribed?
questions.solution:
Beta blockers alleviate glaucoma by decreasing aqueous outflow, not by increasing uveoscleral outflow.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 168

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is on Bethanechol for treatment of urge incontinence. By which transducer mechanism does this drug alleviate the patients symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Visceral smooth muscle contraction and glandular secretions are elicited through M3 receptors, which also mediated vasodilatation through EDRF release.
  • Together the M2 and M3 receptors mediate most of the well-recognized muscarinic actions including contraction of LES.

Bethanechol

It has been used in postoperative/postpartum nonobstructive urinary retention, neurogenic bladder to promote urination. It can afford symptomatic relief in congenital megacolon and gastroesophageal reflux, but is rarely used for these.

Side effects are prominent:

belching, colic, involuntary urination/defecation, flushing, sweating, fall in BP, bronchospasm.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 112-115

questions.text: A 23-year-old approaches her ophthalmologist for LASIK. Her doctor advises her to have a fundoscopy in order to visualize her retina for any pathology as part of the pre-operative checkup. Which of the following agents causing mydriasis should he prefer for the patient given that cycloplegia is not needed?
questions.solution:
• Phenylephrine is an alpha-1 agonist that causes active mydriasis via Gq transducer mechanism. Alpha receptors are not present on ciliary muscles, thus cycloplegia is not seen with sympathomimetics. Thus, they are preferred in patients in whom only fundoscopy is to be done, where cycloplegia has no role.
  • In refractive error testing, mydriasis along with cycloplegia is needed, hence anticholinergics like tropicamide are preferred. These are not potent in children, thus stronger mydriatics like atropine are preferred in children. These agents are contraindicated in glaucoma.
  • Bethanechol is a parasympathomimetic and causes active miosis.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 131

questions.text:
A 51-year-old diabetic approaches his physician with the following blood report.
Fasting blood sugar- 133 mg/dL
Postprandial blood sugar- 200mg/dL
HbA1c- 8.8%
Which of these agents, apart from insulin can the physician prescribe to her, which can manage both Type-1 and type-2 diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
• Amylin, also called 'islet amyloid polypeptide' (IAP), is produced by pancreatic β cells and is stored in the same granules as insulin.
  • As such, it is secreted along with insulin, acts in the brain to reduce glucagon secretion from α cells, delay gastric emptying, retard glucose absorption and promote satiety.
  • Pramlintide is a synthetic amylin analogue which on s.c. injection before meal attenuates postprandial glycaemia and exerts a centrally mediated anorectic action.
  • The duration of action is 2-3 hours. It is used to supplement meal time insulin injection when insulin alone fails to control postprandial glycaemic peak, in both type 1 and type 2 diabetics.
  • Hypoglycaemia is the most important adverse effect. loss of appetite, nausea and vomiting are the other side effects. Reduction in body weight is an additional benefit.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 293

questions.text: A patient of Graves' disease experienced hyperpyrexia, tachycardia and palpitations after missing 2 doses of Methimazole being prescribed to her. She was immediately admitted and resuscitated. One of the medications being administered to her during this time was Propranolol. How does this medication help alleviate the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
• The condition here is thyrotoxicosis, which is due to decompensated hyperthyroidism.
  • Propranolol (and other nonselective β blockers) have emerged as an important form of therapy to rapidly alleviate manifestations of thyrotoxicosis that are due to sympathetic overactivity, viz. palpitation, tremor, nervousness, severe myopathy, sweating. They have little effect on thyroid function and the hypermetabolic state.
  • They afford dramatic symptomatic relief in thyroid storm. In addition, higher doses reduce peripheral conversion of T4 to T3
  • Rehydration, anxiolytics and external cooling are cornerstone for resuscitation.
  • Other drugs given are-
  • Propylthiouracil, iopanoic acid, hydrocortisone, diltiazem when beta blockers are contraindicated

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 278

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient came to OPD with chief complaints of weight gain, excessive sweating, widening of both hands and feet for 4 to 5 years. She also complains of change in voice. But patient's general appearance didn't look normal. Careful examination from head to toe showed prominent supraorbital ridges, prognathism, widening of teeth spaces, macroglossia with thick lips, large ears and a fleshy nose. The patient also had spade like hands and feet as shown below. A diagnosis of Acromegaly was confirmed with imaging. The patient was administered a drug known as pegvisomant. While prescribing this drug, which of these will you routinely perform to check for known adverse effects?
questions.solution:
• The clinical vignette above describes Acromegaly, which is due to GH excess in adults.
  • Pegvisomant is a GH receptor antagonist which is used for the treatment for acromegaly. It causes visual field defects as an adverse effect.

Pegvisomant.

Pegvisomant is approved for the treatment of acromegaly. It is a GH analogue with amino acid substitutions that disrupt the interaction at GH site 2, effectively functioning as a GHR antagonist.

Pegvisomant should not be used in patients with an unexplained elevation of hepatic transaminases, and liver function tests should be monitored in all patients. In addition, lipohypertrophy has occurred at injection sites.

Because of concerns that loss of negative feedback by GH and IGF-1 may increase the growth of GH-secreting adenomas, careful follow-up by pituitary MRI is strongly recommended.

Reference: Goodman and Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, page no. 929

questions.text: Monica presented to the ophthalmology OPD with complaints of redness, photophobia, lacrimation and blurring of vision for 3 days. There is no reported history of trauma. She has a history of frequent 'cold sores. Examination by fluorescent staining revealed findings are given below. Which of the following will not be prescribed to her?
questions.solution:
• The clinical features of redness, blurring, photophobia along with dendritic ulcers on staining point to a diagnosis of HSV keratitis.
  • HSV epithelial keratitis invariably involves active viral proliferation.
  • The classic epithelial dendrite is the most common presentation of epithelial disease. It represents areas of epithelial breakdown due to cell destruction by proliferating virus and is best demonstrated after fluorescein staining under cobalt blue lighting.
  • Adjacent epithelium stains with rose Bengal in a 'terminal bulb' configuration and represents intact, virally-infected epithelium.
  • In immunocompetent individuals the herpetic epithelial disease is self-limited and will resolve, even in the absence of pharmacologic intervention.
  • Faint anterior stromal opacities corresponding to the dendritic epithelial defect (often referred to as 'footprints') may persist for some time and should not be mistaken for active stromal disease.
  • It is generally treated with topical or oral antivirals such as acyclovir. Antibacterial eye drops may be given to prevent secondary bacterial infection. Steroids are contraindicated in epithelial diseases to avoid perforation. They may be given in herpes stromal or endothelial pathologies.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 319

questions.text: A 49-year-old breast cancer patient presented with a breast lump on the right breast. Examination and investigation revealed a stage-2 cancer of the breast, which was ER, PR Positive. Accordingly, the patient was started on a class of drugs known as SERM's. Apart from the beneficial effect on breast tissue, on which of the following will this drug offer a beneficial action?
questions.solution:
• Tamoxifene is a common SERM, selective estrogen receptor modulator given to CA breast patients. It has an agonistic action on breast, bone (decreased resorption) and blood (Lipid profile).
  • However, it has an antagonist action and increases the risk of endometrial cancer and thromboembolism.
  • Other SERM's are clomiphene, raloxifene, bazedoxifene, ospemifene and ormeloxifene.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 337

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presented to the OPD with complaints of arthralgia and myalgia. His face revealed a butterfly shaped malar rash that spared the nasolabial folds and swelling He reported being on treatment for DOTS TB for 6 months. His medical history is also significant for depression for which he was taking fluoxetine. He had suffered tinea infection a month back for which he was given terbinafine ointment Investigations revealed a positive ANA and dsDNA titer and low complement levels. Which of the drugs in his prescription could have caused his current condition?
questions.solution:
• The above scenario describes drug induced SLE, which is caused by drugs which are metabolized by acetylation.
  • Other drugs causing SLE are
  • Sulfonamides
  • Hydralazine
  • Isoniazid
  • Procainamide

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 817

questions.text: A 49-year-old alcoholic patient was diagnosed with cirrhosis and was being investigated for any complications. He is currently disoriented and drowsy. He is also experiencing limb tremors. The physician suspects a hepatic encephalopathy and accordingly, neomycin was given to him for gut sterilization. Which of the following will you monitor while the patient is on neomycin?
questions.solution:
• Neomycin is preferred for gut sterilization in hepatic encephalopathy and clears the offending agent, i.e., NH3.
  • It is an aminoglycoside that has the maximum nephrotoxicity
  • It results from toxicity to proximal tubular cells and is almost always reversible.
  • Risk factors for nephrotoxicity include hypokalemia, pre-existing renal disease and concomitant nephrotoxic medications (like AMB, vancomycin etc.).
  • Neomycin is most nephrotoxic and is not indicated for systemic use.
  • Among the systemically used aminoglycosides, gentamicin is most nephrotoxic followed by tobramycin. Streptomycin is least nephrotoxic

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 795

choices.text: Blocks tRNA from binding to A site

questions.text: A neonate was administered a certain antimicrobial agent, following which he developed 'gray baby syndrome'. By which mechanism does this protein synthesis inhibitor stop bacterial growth?
questions.solution:
• Gray baby syndrome is a side effect of chloramphenicol, which inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to 50s subunit and blocks transfer of the elongating peptide chain to the newly attached aminoacyl-tRNA.
  • Gray baby syndrome occurs when high doses (~100 mg/kg) are given prophylactically to neonates, especially premature. The baby stops feeding, vomited, becomes hypotonic and hypothermic, abdomen distended, respiration becomes irregular; an ashen gray cyanosis develops in many, followed by cardiovascular collapse and death. blood lactic acid was raised.
  • It occurs because of the inability of the newborn to adequately metabolize and excrete chloramphenicol. Chloramphenicol should be avoided in neonates.

Other options-

  1. Misreading of RNA is caused by aminoglycosides
  2. Blocking of t-RNA from binding is caused by tetracycline
  3. Translocation is inhibited by Macrolides, linezolid, streptogramins and lincosamides

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 791

questions.text: Prerna is a 25-year-old girl who experienced malaise, runny nose, cough and low grade fever for 5 days. Her viral PCR report was positive for influenza virus. The doctor prescribed her a drug due to which she developed the following side effect. By which mechanism does this drug inhibit viral replication?
questions.solution:
• The above image shows livedo reticularis, which is a known side effect of the M2 protein inhibitor Amantadine.
  • It refers to a netlike pattern of reddish-blue skin discoloration. The legs are often affected.
  • The condition is linked to swollen blood vessels. It may get worse when the temperature is cold. Amantadine is used for treatment of influenza A and is also used as an add on Parkinson's disease.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 853

questions.text: A 72-year-old man, Ram was admitted to the ER for Shortness of breath and cough and high-grade fever of 102.F. He had an episode of an acute exacerbation of asthma 5 days ago, for which he was given inhaled salbutamol, inhaled prednisolone and levofloxacin to prevent secondary bacterial infection. The patient has been asthmatic since 50 years. His saturation on room air was 80%. Examination revealed bilateral diffuse wheezing and pharyngeal wall erythema. Electrocardiogram was normal and chest X-ray was without any infiltrate. Peak expiratory flow rate was 200 L/min. Diagnostic impression was asthma exacerbation secondary to acute bronchitis. Intravenous methylprednisolone 40 mg every 8 hours, bronchodilators, and levofloxacin were given. Serum mycoplasma antibody, urine legionella antigen, nasal swab for respiratory syncytial virus and influenza antigen, and rapid streptococcal throat tests were negative. On day 5 of admission, a high-resolution contrast tomographic (HRCT) scanning of the chest revealed bilateral multifocal ground glass opacities. Sputum study revealed aspergillus infection. What is the drug of choice for invasive aspergillosis?
questions.solution:
• Voriconazole is the drug of choice for invasive aspergillosis. It is a triazole that inhibits 14 alpha de-methylase, thus inhibiting ergosterol synthesis.
  • Voriconazole is the drug of choice for invasive aspergillosis, disseminated infections caused by fluconazole resistant Candida, Fusarium infections, and febrile neutropenia not responding to antibacterial therapy. It is also active against histoplasmosis and blastomycosis. Serious cases are first treated i.v. followed by oral voriconazole.
  • It is completely absorbed orally, except when taken with a fatty meal, widely distributed into tissues and metabolized extensively by CYP2C19, CYP3A4, CYP2C9. Metabolites are excreted in urine. The t1⁄2 is 6 hours. Voriconazole is also an inhibitor of CYP isoenzymes and the drug interaction profile is similar to itraconazole.
  • Rashes, photosensitivity, rise in liver enzymes and QTc prolongation can occur. Short lasting visual disturbances are common after i.v. injection, and an acute reaction is also possible.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 846

questions.text:
Manohar is a resident of Bihar presenting with Fever, fatigue and weight loss for 14 days. He is a farmer by profession. His vitals are
Temperature-100.3F, Pulse 100bpm, RR-12/min, BP- 128/84 mmHg. On examination, marked splenomegaly is noted. His blood report shows the following-
Hb- 10g%
WBC- 2000/mL
Platelets- 80,000/mm3
Hematocrit- 49%
His dipstick was positive for rk-39 antigen. However, since he had travelled from a village, he refused to be admitted and asked for a tablet. Which of the following oral drugs can be prescribed for this condition?
questions.solution:
• The clinical vignette with a resident of an endemic area with complains of fever, splenomegaly and pancytopenia, along with a positive dipstick for rk-39 antigen points towards a diagnosis of Visceral leishmaniasis (Kala-Azar), which is caused by a protozoa and its vector is sandfly.
  • The drug of choice for visceral leishmaniasis is L-AMB but the oral drug of choice is Miltefosine.
  • The mechanism of anti-leishmania action of miltefosine is not known. However, studies suggest that it may be interfering with lipid metabolism of the parasite or prevent synthesis of some critical cell surface anchor molecules, or alter signal transduction.
  • Leishmania can develop resistance to miltefosine and this may be due to mutation limiting transport of the drug into the parasite cell.
  • Its side effects include nausea, vomiting and diarrhea
  • Sodium stibogluconate is given for cutaneous leishmaniasis. Ketoconazole may also be tried.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 903

questions.text: Manish, a 24-year-old man is suffering from Hodgkin's Lymphoma. He has been prescribed an ABVD regimen for the same. After a few months, he arrives at the Emergency Department with bleeding from a minor bruise which continued for 5 hours. On lab testing, his platelet counts were 7,000/cubic mm. Which of the following drug is used for long-term management of] drug-induced Thrombocytopenia?
questions.solution:
• Oprelvekin is a recombinant IL-11. It increases platelet count by stimulating megakaryocyte proliferation and differentiation, stimulates hepatic synthesis of acute-phase proteins and promotes the development of neurons.
  • Adverse effects of Oprelvekin include gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., nausea, vomiting) and
  • water retention (e.g., edema, pleural effusion).
  • Other Options:
  1. Filgrastim is a recombinant G-CSF
  2. Sargramostim is a recombinant GM-CSF
  3. Dabrapoetin is a recombinant EPO

Reference: Goodman and Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, page no. 906

questions.text: Which of the following drug is not used for opioid-induced constipation?
questions.solution:
• Opioid-induced constipation is seen as recent initiation of an opioid or dose adjustment with new or worsening constipation, fecal impaction may be present.
  • OIC is a clinical diagnosis based on Rome IV diagnostic criteria.
  • Treatment is similar to Primary Constipation:
  • Identify and treat any underlying organic cause.
  • Lifestyle and dietary modification
  • Evaluate the need for opiate therapy and discontinue/reduce the dose if appropriate.
  • Medical therapy
  • Laxative therapy
  • Osmotic laxative and/or stimulant laxative
  • Options for laxative-refractory OIC: Peripherally acting μ-opioid receptor antagonists (Alvemopan, Naloxegol, Naldemedine, Methylnaltrexone)

Methylnaltrexone

It is an opioid antagonist (primarily m receptor) that does not penetrate blood-brain barrier, but acts on opioid receptors in the gut. Methylnaltrexone has been used to counteract opioid analgesic induced constipation in cancer/palliative care patients without blocking the analgesic action.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 726

questions.text: Rose, an 18-year-old primi came to the clinic complaining about severe nausea and vomiting at 10 weeks of gestation. She complained about feeling exhausted and dehydrated. On examination, her pulse was 110 per minute, BP was 90/60 mm-Hg and SpO2 was 99%. What is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
• This pregnant lady is suffering from Morning Sickness. Nausea and vomiting are common conditions of pregnancy and are typically treated with hydration and nonpharmacological methods. If nausea is refractory to nonpharmacological methods, antiemetics should be started in a step-wise manner.
  • Hyperemesis gravidarum is a severe form of nausea and vomiting during pregnancy characterized by ketonuria and weight loss and typically requires inpatient admission, intravenous fluid hydration, and antiemetic therapy.
  • Antiemetic therapy for nausea and vomiting of pregnancy: If the response to an antiemetic from one class is inadequate, add an antiemetic from another class in a stepwise manner, as shown below:
  1. Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) and/or doxylamine
  2. For refractory symptoms, add one of the following:
  • Diphenhydramine
  • Dimenhydrinate
  • Prochlorperazine
  • Promethazine
  1. For refractory symptoms despite combination therapy above, add one of the following:
  • Metoclopramide
  • Ondansetron
  • Promethazine
  1. Last resort: Add chlorpromazine or methylprednisolone.
  2. Thiamine repletion (in patients with severe recurrent vomiting)

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 711

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl, Sanju, with a history of severe persistent asthma. She continues to wheeze and cough multiple nights per week. She has allergies to pollen and shellfish, but her mother denies any recent exposure. The patient's medications include albuterol, salmeterol, and both inhaled and oral prednisone. What alternative drug can the pediatrician recommend for this patient?
questions.solution:
• The pediatrician can recommend omalizumab to improve symptom control and reduce the burden of steroids in the patient's medication regimen.
  • Omalizumab is a recombinant IgG monoclonal antibody that selectively binds to human IgE.
  • This inhibits binding of IgE to IgE receptors on mast cell and basophil surfaces, thus reducing release of allergic mediators.
  • It is approved for use in children 12 years or older with moderate to severe persistent asthma on maximal medical therapy but inadequate symptom control from corticosteroids.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 251

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman, Malala, presents with long-standing history of chronic dyspnea and fatigue. She has a mutation in the BMPR2 gene. Physical examination reveals an increased P2 on auscultation. Her physician recommends starting a medication to slow the patient's clinical worsening that requires regular monitoring of liver function tests. This medication has which of the following mechanisms of action?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with dyspnea, a BMPR2 gene mutation, and an increased P2 suggestive of idiopathic pulmonary hypertension.
  • Bosentan is an endothelin-1 receptor antagonist that is used to slow disease progression in patients with idiopathic pulmonary hypertension and is known to be hepatotoxic.
  • Idiopathic pulmonary hypertension is treated with calcium channel blockers, endothelin-1 receptor antagonists, or phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors.
  • Calcium channel blockers are considered the first-line agent in the absence of contraindications; however, this patient failed calcium channel blockers due to drug toxicity (severe edema).
  • Therefore, bosentan, an endothelin-1 receptor antagonist, is indicated to slow disease progression. Endothelins are vasoconstrictive peptides and thus their inhibition at the endothelin-1 receptor leads to decreased vasoconstriction.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 546-547

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman presents for her annual check-up. She has no current complaints and says that she has been healthy over the last year. Her past medical history is significant for obesity and diabetes that is well controlled on metformin. Lab results are shown below:
HDL 48 mg/dL
LDL 192 mg/dL
TGs 138 mg/dL
Given these results, the patient is placed on the drug that will be the best therapy for these findings. Which of the following is a potential side effect of this treatment?
questions.solution:
• This patient has significantly elevated LDL but relatively normal TGs and HDL. The most effective treatment for high LDL levels is a statin, which has a side effect of hepatotoxicity.
  • HMG-CoA reductase is the rate-limiting step in cholesterol production. Therefore, inhibitors of this enzyme, known as statins, are the most effective drugs to treat elevated LDL levels. They are used to decrease mortality in patients with coronary artery disease and can be used to decrease LDL levels in all patients.
  • Important toxicities of statins are hepatotoxicity and myopathy, especially when used in combination with fibrates and niacin. Inhibitors of the P450 enzymes can increase serum concentrations of statins.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 686

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents for his yearly checkup. His past medical history is significant for obesity, hypertension, diabetes, hypercholesterolemia, and hyperlipidemia. Based on these findings, his physician prescribes a drug that leads to a large decrease in TGs with a much smaller increase in HDL and a decrease in LDL. The drug that was most likely prescribed in this case is associated with which of the following side effects?
questions.solution:
• Given the large decrease in triglycerides, this patient was most likely prescribed Fibrates, which is associated with the side effect of cholelithiasis.
  • Fibrates such as gemfibrozil and fenofibrate function by stimulating intracellular PPAR-α, which subsequently activates lipoprotein lipase. Since lipoprotein lipase is one of the major proteins associated with the clearance of triglycerides from circulating lipoproteins, fibrates are associated with a dramatic decrease in triglyceride levels.
  • These drugs also cause a minor increase in HDL and a minor decrease or no change in LDL. Important side effects to be aware of include the development of cholelithiasis and muscle myopathy.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 687

questions.text:
A 61-year-old woman presents with left leg pain and swelling. A lower extremity ultrasound demonstrates a deep venous thrombosis in the left femoral vein. Results from a complete blood count are within normal limits. She is discharged on low-molecular-weight heparin.
Seven days later, she presents to the emergency room with a dark erythematous skin lesion on her left thigh and worsening left leg swelling. A lower extremity ultrasound demonstrates a persistent deep venous thrombosis in the left femoral vein as well as a new deep venous thrombosis in the left popliteal vein. Results of a complete blood count are shown below:
Hemoglobin: 13.1 g/dL
Hematocrit: 38%
WBC count: 9,600/mm^3 with normal differential
Platelet count: 74,000/mm^3
A medication with which of the following mechanisms of action is most appropriate to initiate in this patient after stopping the heparin drip?
questions.solution:
• The patient in this vignette presents with new-onset thrombosis and thrombocytopenia following heparin administration suggestive of type II heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). Direct thrombin inhibitors such as Bivalirudin can be used as a anticoagulate in patients following HIT.
  • Type II HIT is characterized by a hypercoagulable state that normally presents 5-10 days after heparin exposure with thrombocytopenia and venous thrombosis. The first step in managing HIT is to stop all heparin-containing products. Direct thrombin inhibitors such as bivalirudin, argatroban, and lepirudin can be used to continue anticoagulation. Once platelet levels normalize, patients may be transitioned to warfarin for prolonged anticoagulation.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 665

choices.text: Prevents dopamine degradation by MAO enzyme
Prevents dopamine degradation by COMT enzyme

questions.text: A 49-year-old man presents with complaints of weakness and fatigue. He has started moving slower than normal and has noticed difficulty buttoning up his pants or tying his tie. He has a tremor in his right hand that diminishes when he is instructed to hold a pen in his hand. His physician prescribes multiple medications including a drug that is also indicated in the treatment of prolactinomas. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of this medication?
questions.solution:
• The patient in this vignette presents with resting tremors and bradykinesia suggestive of Parkinson's disease. Bromocriptine is a dopamine agonist that is used to treat Parkinson's disease and prolactinomas.
  • The primary metabolic disturbance in Parkinson's disease is decreased dopamine signaling.
  • Bromocriptine is a dopamine receptor agonist that is used to restore the balance in dopamine signaling in Parkinson's disease.
  • It is also used to treat hyperprolactinemia in the setting of a prolactinoma.
  • Dopamine inhibits prolactin secretion, so dopamine agonists such as bromocriptine and cabergoline effectively inhibit excess prolactin secretion.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 457

choices.text: Increased frequency of GABAA channel opening
Inhibition of presynaptic voltage-activated Ca2+ channels
Blockade of thalamic T-type calcium channels

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy with a 2-week history of frequent episodes of unresponsiveness. During these episodes, he stares blankly, rhythmically nods his head, and does not respond to verbal stimulation for several seconds. Hyperventilation for 30 seconds precipitates an episode of unresponsiveness and head nodding that lasts for 7 seconds. He regains consciousness immediately afterward. An electroencephalogram shows 3-Hz spikes and waves. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
• This boy has childhood absence epilepsy. Absence seizures typically manifest with episodes of staring, inattentiveness, and head nodding and can be triggered by hyperventilation.
  • Patients typically maintain muscle tone during seizures and do not experience a postictal phase. The diagnosis is confirmed with EEG findings of a 3-Hz spike and wave pattern. First-line therapy is Ethosuximide, which works by blocking T-type calcium channels.
  • Other Options:
  1. BZDs
  2. Gabapentin
  3. Vigabatrin

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 443-448

questions.text: A 73-year-old female has started to get lost in places that she is familiar with, like in her neighborhood while walking to the temple. She also has difficulty remembering to pay her bills. Her mini-mental status exam score is 19/30. Work up for secondary causes of cognitive decline is negative. Which of the following should be included in the patient's medication regimen to slow the progression of the disease?
questions.solution:
• An elderly female presenting with progressive cognitive deficits without other medical conditions is likely to be suffering from Alzheimer's disease.
  • She should be treated with cholinesterase inhibitors like Rivastigmine, Donepezil, etc., or NMDA antagonist like Memantine.
  • Alzheimer's disease is a disease that progresses over a period of years and presents with amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tau tangles in the brain.
  • It is characterized by progressive memory loss and cognitive decline that may result in the patient's inability to perform activities of daily living (ADLs) such as paying bills, driving to usual locations, and cooking and cleaning the house.
  • It is more common in women and patients above 65 years of age. It results from the destruction of the cholinergic neurons resulting in an acetylcholine deficiency, manifesting as cognitive decline.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 519

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy with cerebral palsy is about to undergo a femoral osteotomy. An intravenous catheter needs to be placed; however, given the prior experience, the boy is extremely anxious and does not want to be stuck with a needle while awake. An inhalation agent that would anesthetize most quickly has which of the following characteristics?
questions.solution:
• This patient who is going to have anesthesia induced by mask administration will be receiving an inhaled anesthetic. The fastest inhaled anesthetic will have a low blood solubility.
  • Inhaled anesthetics can be characterized by their potency as well as their speed of achieving a steady state.
  • The potency of an inhaled anesthetic is inversely related to the minimal alveolar concentration, which is the concentration of gas required to prevent 50% of patients from moving in response to a noxious stimulus.
  • The more lipid soluble a gas is, the higher the potency of the anesthetic. The speed of induction relates to how quickly the gas can distribute from the alveoli into the blood and ultimately to the brain.
  • Since the gas is transported by blood but blood is not the final site of action, gases with lower blood solubility will saturate this compartment more quickly and allow for faster redistribution to the brain.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 403

questions.text: A patient with a history of hypertension and bipolar disorder is seen in your clinic for new-onset tremors, as well as intense thirst and frequent desire to urinate. Recently a new drug was added to her regimen. Which of the following medications did she likely start?
questions.solution:
• Lithium toxicity (symptoms of which include tremor and polyuria/polydipsia) can result from renal injury, toxins, or the addition of ACE inhibitors, thiazide diuretics, or NSAIDs. Loop diuretics do not increase lithium toxicity.
  • Bipolar disorder is characterized by episodes of mania (bipolar I) OR hypomania (bipolar II) AND depression.
  • The most common first-line treatment is lithium, although anticonvulsants such as valproate and antipsychotics such as olanzapine may also be used if lithium is not tolerated.
  • Symptoms of lithium toxicity include fine hand tremor, hypothyroidism, polyuria, and polydipsia (nephrogenic diabetes insipidus). Side effects due to the addition of another medication require cessation of the offending drug.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 476

questions.text: Psychiatrist prescribes a medication that addresses both depression & smoking cessation. Which of the following would be a contraindication for the drug that was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
• Antidepressants can be classified based on their effects on neurotransmitters. First-line therapy is SSRIs that work by increasing the concentration of serotonin. Other antidepressants with a similar mechanism of action include SNRIs and TCAs.
  • Atypical antidepressants (such as bupropion, mirtazapine, and trazadone) have a variety of mechanisms of action and therefore have secondary effects that may be helpful in specific situations. Distinguishing between antidepressants requires recognition of these secondary effects as well as characteristic side effects.
  • In this case, assistance with smoking cessation is a feature of only bupropion. An important contraindication to bupropion use is anorexia or bulimia since these patients may have seizures if treated with bupropion.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 486

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the clinic complaining of erectile dysfunction and is prescribed medication. The drug binds to the same active site on the phosphodiesterase-5 enzyme as cGMP to prevent the enzyme from working. Assuming the patient's pre-medication baseline is demonstrated on Curve A, which of the following curves (image) shows the patient's enzyme activity after drug administration?
questions.solution:
• Sildenafil is a competitive inhibitor that changes Km (Michaelis constant) without changing Vmax (maximum reaction velocity).
  • This activity corresponds to curve B.
  • Competitive inhibitors bind to the same active site on the enzyme as the substrate to inhibit enzyme activity.
  • They increase Km (the substrate concentration at which ½ Vmax is reached) without changing Vmax.
  • Competitive inhibitors can be outcompeted by increasing the substrate concentration.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 46-47

choices.text: Decreased loading dose and decreased maintenance dose
Decreased loading dose and same maintenance dose
Increased loading dose and same maintenance dose
Same loading dose and decreased maintenance dose

questions.text: Compared with the male patient, which of the following is true about administering this drug to the female patient? (Assuming both have different body weights but the same renal clearance for this drug)
questions.solution:
• These patients who have different body mass but the same drug clearance will require the same maintenance dose but different loading doses with the smaller patient requiring a lower loading dose.
  • The loading dose of medication will depend upon the target plasma concentration of the drug as well as the volume of distribution for the patient.
  • The volume of distribution is the theoretical volume that the drug can enter, which will depend upon the mass of the patient.
  • A fat-soluble drug will be able to disperse through all fatty tissues, and a larger patient will have a larger volume of distribution. It is insensitive to the clearance method as well as renal or liver function.
  • In contrast, the maintenance dose is the dose required to maintain a target plasma drug concentration after that level has already been reached.
  • This dose will depend only on the clearance of the drug by the kidney or the liver. It is insensitive to the volume of distribution.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 41-42

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman, Shrutika presents 6 hours after ingesting three bottles of aspirin. She complains of nausea, vomiting, dizziness, and tinnitus. Her blood pressure is 135/80 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respirations are 32/min, temperature is 100.1 deg F (37.8 deg C), and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Arterial blood gas at room air shows, PCO2 11 mmHg, and PO2 129 mmHg. Blood salicylate level is 55 mg/dL. Management should involve which of the following acid-base principles?
questions.solution:
• This vignette describes a patient experiencing salicylate toxicity. Management involves increasing excretion via serum and urine alkalization.
  • Free, unbound drugs are filtered into the urine. Both ionized and un-ionized forms of a drug are filtered, but only ionized forms are 'trapped' in the filtrate because they cannot easily cross the bilayer membranes of the cells that construct the nephron.
  • Un-ionized forms can be reabsorbed in the distal tubule and collecting duct. In this case, salicylate is a weak acid.
  • Thus, it can be further ionized via alkalization of the urine to increase urinary excretion. Serum alkalization is just as important to reduce salicylic acid buildup in the central nervous system.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 17

questions.text: A researcher is studying the properties of a new pain medication that she believes may be safer than currently available alternatives. She performs a trial where she measures the dosage of medication needed to provide adequate pain relief in patients with osteoarthritis. She also collects data on the dosage of medication at which patients started experiencing respiratory depression or other toxic effects. The results of this study are plotted in the image. Which of the following best represents the therapeutic index of this drug?
questions.solution:
• The therapeutic index of a drug is defined as TD50/ED50 (toxic dose for 50% of patients/effective dose for 50% of patients). In this case, the therapeutic index can be calculated by 66/22 = 3.
  • The therapeutic index is a measurement of drug safety that describes the relationship between the dosages needed for therapeutic and toxic effects.
  • It can be calculated by dividing the dosage at which 50% of patients experience a toxic effect (TD50) by the dosage at which 50% of patients experience a therapeutic effect (ED50).
  • A safer drug will have a higher therapeutic index insofar as a small dose will be effective and a much larger dose is needed to cause a toxic response.
  • Drugs with smaller therapeutic indexes such as warfarin, lithium, and amphotericin require regular monitoring of drug levels because they can become extremely toxic past a narrow range of concentrations.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 65

questions.text: A 37-year-old female with SLE is started on a new regimen of corticosteroids to better control her symptoms. The physician goes on to state that corticosteroids can also cause a number of hematological changes. Which figure correctly identifies the cell type that would be expected to INCREASE as a result of corticosteroid use?
questions.solution:
• Corticosteroids cause an increased neutrophil (Option A) count via de-margination.
  • Corticosteroids are powerful anti-inflammatory medications and are used to treat a number of conditions including arthritis, temporal arteritis, dermatitis, allergic reactions, asthma, hepatitis, systemic lupus erythematosus, and inflammatory bowel disease.
  • While powerful and often effective, corticosteroids have a number of side effects including weight gain, hirsutism, skin changes, and increased emotional lability.
  • Additionally, they can cause leukocytosis via de-margination.
  • De-margination refers to neutrophils having difficulty exiting the vasculature and thus causing an increase in their numbers in the bloodstream leading to neutrophilia.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 309-310

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after he punched his mother and siblings at home. On presentation, his mother says that his personality has changed dramatically over the last 3 months from being a kind boy who was achieving straight A grades to an aggressive boy who gets into fights and fails his classes. He has no past psychiatric history and his mom is worried because she feels like her son has changed in front of her eyes. A physical exam reveals a shuffling gait as well as strange flinging movements of his arms. Which of the following should be administered to this patient?
questions.solution:
• This patient with acute onset personality changes in his early teens, shuffling gait, and hemiballismus most likely has Wilson disease, which can be treated using the copper chelator penicillamine.
  • Wilson disease is caused by a mutation in the ATP7B channel that leads to the accumulation of free copper in tissues.
  • One notable organ that is affected by this excess copper is the brain, so neurologic and psychiatric changes are often the first presenting signs of the disease. Psychiatric symptoms can include abrupt increases in aggression and forgetfulness in a teenager.
  • Neurologic symptoms can include Parkinson-like manifestations such as shuffling gait as well as hemiballismus.
  • Treatment of Wilson's disease involves removal of the excess copper using the copper chelation agent penicillamine.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 699

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman comes to the clinic complaining of intermittent, gnawing epigastric pain for the past 2 months. The pain is exacerbated with food and has been getting progressively worse. Her medical history is significant for chronic back pain for which she takes ibuprofen. Labs show reduced hemoglobin levels. To what medication is most appropriate to be switched from the current medication at this time?
questions.solution:
• This patient has peptic ulcer disease (PUD) secondary to chronic non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) use. Acetaminophen would be the most appropriate medication to switch to as it is a non-NSAID that would address her chronic pain without exacerbating her PUD.
  • The patient's low hemoglobin and the quality of pain support PUD more so than GERD. PUD can be a result of chronic NSAID use, as seen here in this patient.
  • The damage occurs via inhibition of COX-1 at the upper gastrointestinal tract, which reduces the mucosal generation of protective prostaglandins leading to mucosal damage.
  • The patient has been reportedly using ibuprofen for a long time for her chronic pain, along with her age, which places her at high risk for the development of PUD secondary to NSAID use. To avoid further damage, patients are encouraged to use analgesics that have minimal effects on COX-1, such as acetaminophen.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 223

questions.text: A 54-year-old male, Rajiv has a history of gout complicated by several prior episodes of acute gouty arthritis and 3 prior instances of nephrolithiasis secondary to uric acid stones. He has a serum uric acid level of 11 mg/dL (normal range 3-8 mg/dL), a 24 hr urine collection of 1300 mg uric acid (normal range 250-750 mg), and a serum creatinine of 0.8 mg/dL with a normal estimated glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Uricosuric drugs, such as probenecid, should be avoided in patients with high uric acid excretion (generally, > 800 mg/24hr is indicative of a uric acid overproducer) because this increases the risk of forming uric acid stones.
  • Uricosuric medications should only be used in patients who under-excrete uric acid.
  • These agents should not be used in patients with a history of kidney stones unless the stones have been confirmed to NOT be uric acid stones. Patients taking uricosuric agents should be instructed to have high fluid intake to minimize the risk of uric acid precipitation and stone formation.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 232

questions.text: In a surgery, a 61-year-old man is administered an agent that results in fasciculations in the patient's extremities. After a while, the fasciculations stop and remain stopped for the remainder of the surgery. Consider the period of time during which the patient had fasciculations and subsequently the period of time after the fasciculations stopped. If the effects of the administered agent needed to be reversed during each of these two time periods respectively, which of the following agents should be administered during each time period?
questions.solution:
• This patient with fasciculations that then stopped was most likely administered succinylcholine, which cannot be reversed during phase I and can be reversed with neostigmine during phase II.
  • Depolarizing neuromuscular blockers such as succinylcholine work by binding to nicotinic receptors and result in a blockade in two phases.
  • During phase I depolarization, sustained depolarization by these agents (seen as fasciculations) renders the muscle unable to exhibit coordinated contractions. In phase I there is no antidote and the duration of the block would be prolonged by acetylcholinesterase inhibitors.
  • During phase II, the receptors are repolarized but have become desensitized. The antidote in this phase is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor such as neostigmine, which functions by overcoming the desensitization by raising the concentration of acetylcholine present in the synapse.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 376

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because of multiple episodes of headache over the past 3 months. The headaches last the entire day and are unilateral and throbbing. During the headaches, she has severe nausea and is unable to work and perform her daily activities. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy for the long-term prevention of headaches in this patient?
questions.solution:
• This woman has clinical features that suggest migraine headache: a prodrome (unusual appetite prior to the headache) followed by a unilateral throbbing headache with nausea that is incapacitating.
  • Beta-blockers (e.g., propranolol) are usually the first-line drugs for long-term prophylaxis of migraine headaches. Other drugs that may be used for migraine prophylaxis include anticonvulsants such as topiramate and sodium valproate. Tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline) are second-line options.
  • Migraine prophylaxis is indicated for patients with frequent attacks (≥ 3 attacks/month), long-lasting attacks (e.g., > 12-24 hours), and migraine that is preceded by an aura. Other non-pharmacological therapeutic measures include lifestyle changes (e.g., exercise in moderation), avoidance of potential triggers, progressive muscle relaxation, and biofeedback training.
  • Beta-blockers are also the preferred agents for the prevention of migraine headaches during pregnancy.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 195

questions.text: A 40-year-old male complained that his vision has deteriorated within 1 hour that he can no longer see. He explains that some acquaintances sold him some homemade liquor. Which of the following if administered immediately after drinking the liquor would have saved his vision?
questions.solution:
• During the fermentation process, methanol is created as a byproduct, but its concentration in moonshine is typically low.
  • If moonshine is created in large quantities, it can contain a large amount of methanol, and if imbibed can have serious side effects.
  • As mentioned in the question, pure methanol will burn with a yellow flame and pure ethanol with a blue flame, but if there are minor impurities of methanol in ethanol, the yellow flame may not appear.
  • Blindness can occur with ingestion of as small as 30 mLs, with death occurring at 100 mLs.
  • Toxicity is due to the metabolic byproduct of methanol metabolism, formic acid, which is toxic to the optic nerve.
  • Treatment for methanol toxicity includes fomepizole, a competitive inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase, which is preferable but costly. IV ethanol is another option, which competes with methanol for binding sites on ethanol dehydrogenase, preventing the metabolism of methanol.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 423
